importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei made a prediction in March 2025 about AI writing 90% of code within three to six months.
Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg made a prediction in April 2025 about AI contributing to half of a project's development within the next year.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on developments and debates about AI in software engineering from mid-2025 to present, reflecting current industry claims, skepticism, and real-world impacts.

keyTakeAways: Tech CEOs such as Dario Amodei, Mark Zuckerberg, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are making bold claims about AI writing a majority of code, but engineers remain skeptical.
AI tools are effective for generating quick prototypes and repetitive tasks, but often fail in complex or long-term development, leading to 'death spirals' and unworkable code.
Despite AI's capabilities, every line of generated code must be reviewed by a human engineer — AI remains a tool, not a replacement for human judgment and problem-solving.
Studies show mixed results: while some engineers report modest time savings (e.g., 6.5% in Denmark), others, including experienced open-source engineers, report 19% longer task completion times.
The term 'workslop' describes instances where AI is used inappropriately, leading to messy, unreviewable code and increased workload for colleagues.
Concerns exist about AI reducing the demand for junior software engineers, potentially cutting off future talent pipelines needed to maintain and supervise AI systems.
Environmental and ethical concerns include the massive energy consumption and human content generation required to train large language models.
Many engineers, including Simon Willison, argue that AI's real value lies in specific, well-defined tasks, not in replacing human engineers across the board.

namedEntities.name: Dario Amodei
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He made a bold prediction in March 2025 that AI would write 90% of code within three to six months, setting the tone for the tech industry's enthusiasm about AI in coding.

namedEntities.name: Mark Zuckerberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He predicted in April 2025 that AI would contribute to half of a project's development within a year, reinforcing the narrative of AI's transformative role in software engineering.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is cited as a company where AI tools are widely used, even without justification, and where engineers report pressure to use AI despite mixed productivity outcomes.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google conducted a survey showing that half of software engineers 'somewhat' trust AI responses, indicating widespread skepticism about AI reliability in coding.

namedEntities.name: Microsoft
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Microsoft is listed among companies promoting large language models' coding abilities, contributing to the broader industry trend of AI integration in development workflows.

namedEntities.name: Anthropic
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Anthropic developed Claude Code, an AI tool for generating code, and its CEO Dario Amodei made key claims about AI writing most code, placing it at the center of the AI coding debate.

namedEntities.name: Claude Code
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Claude Code is highlighted as a tool capable of generating and testing code with autonomy, but also criticized for producing unworkable or 'death spiral' code when misused.

namedEntities.name: OpenAI
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Simon Willison, an independent AI researcher, was invited to preview OpenAI’s latest model, showing that AI models are under scrutiny for their actual coding productivity and reliability.

namedEntities.name: Y Combinator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Y Combinator supported Colton Voege’s startup and previously promoted AI as a productivity tool; its current focus on AI-only startups reflects shifting industry priorities.

namedEntities.name: Colton Voege
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key voice of skepticism, having personally tried AI tools and reporting no significant efficiency gains and encountering messy, unreviewable code.

namedEntities.name: Simon Willison
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides expert insight into AI’s limitations, arguing that AI cannot replace human problem-solving and that its benefits depend on context and expertise.

namedEntities.name: Boris Cherny
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head of Anthropic’s Claude Code unit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He emphasized that all AI-generated code must be reviewed by engineers and described AI as a 'thought partner' rather than a full replacement.

namedEntities.name: Thomas Ptacek
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He describes how AI has reduced time for repetitive coding tasks, showing AI's practical utility in specific, familiar workflows.

namedEntities.name: Anders Humlum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He contributed to a national survey in Denmark showing only modest time savings (6.5%) from AI, challenging the perception of AI as a major productivity booster.

namedEntities.name: METR
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: METR conducted a study showing experienced engineers using LLMs took 19% longer to complete tasks — contradicting expectations and highlighting AI’s limitations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Tech CEOs from major companies including Anthropic, Meta, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are promoting AI's role in writing most of the code, claiming transformative productivity gains. However, software engineers such as Colton Voege and Simon Willison express skepticism, noting that AI-generated code often fails in complex tasks, creates unworkable or 'death spiral' outputs, and requires human review and oversight. Studies show mixed results, with some engineers gaining modest time savings (e.g., 6.5% in Denmark) while others report longer task completion times. AI tools are most effective for quick prototypes and repetitive tasks, not for higher-level problem-solving. The industry faces concerns about job displacement for junior engineers, environmental costs, and misuse — such as the 'workslop' phenomenon — where AI is used without justification, resulting in messy, unreviewable code. Despite bold claims, experts agree that human engineers remain essential to code quality, safety, and long-term software success.
title: Tech CEOs Say the Era of 'Code by AI' Is Here — But Engineers Are Skeptical
